prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel has never articulated a “formula” or standard used to balance the various factors relating to selecting a transferee district. Stating one is probably not possible.

The Panel has occasionally used phrases such as “center of gravity” that evoke a more rigorous approach to the selection problem.[1] The “center of gravity” test appears to be simply an analogical approach to similar problems. It has not been widely used by the Panel and is probably of little value in advocacy before the Panel.

The factors discussed in §§ 6:4 to 6:22 are not exhaustive of factors that may be considered by the Panel in determining what district would be the most suitable transferee district. The discussion in §§ 6:4 to 6:22 should give some idea of the relative weighting of the factors. For example, the preference for a district where at least one action is pending is a strong one, and will overcome many other arguments.[2] The discussion and cases cited in § 6:8 reflect this preference. This factor presents essentially a “pass-fail” test, however, and does not offer much guidance in selecting between districts where actions are pending.[3]

Some factors play a role in most cases. The Panel's consideration of the location of evidence is a factor that is probably considered in every case before it. It may become an important factor in those cases where it strongly favors the selection of one district. In that situation, it may outweigh the other factors. In many other cases it is simply a factor that favors one district, while other factors favor another.

The fact that the Panel must typically balance a number of factors presents an opportunity for the effective advocate. An attorney can present the factual considerations relating to selection of a transferee district in a way most likely to result in selection of a desired district. The Panel will not be receptive at all to parochial arguments calculated to persuade it to select an unsuitable district of convenience to a single party or attorney. There may be facets of the litigation not known to the Panel that may be of significance to it in the selection process. In the absence of any particularized information, the case is only a “securities,” “antitrust,” “mass tort,” or “labor” case. The attorneys may be able to demonstrate how it either fits or does not fit the stereotyped rubric. For example, counsel have been able in certain cases to overcome the Panel's strong preference to transfer air crash disaster cases to the district where the crash occurred.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Food Fair Securities Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1301, 1306 (J.P.M.L. 1979). “Center of gravity” as used in this context bears little resemblance to its other uses in law. See, e.g., Phillip I. Blumberg, The Law of Corporate Groups: Procedural Problems in the Law of Parent & Subsidiary Corporations§ 9.03 (1983 & Supp. 2002) (residence of corporation); 16 Am. Jur. 2d, Conflict of Laws §§ 38, 42, 49&73 (1979 & Supp. 1985) (choice of law).
The Panel has also tended to favor a district where many actions are pending over one having only one or a few actions. See § 6:8.
The Panel's treatment of the location of the crash is discussed in § 6:6.
